dialogs.original: The good time of day to you, sir.
dialogs.translated: Good day, sir.

dialogs.original: I also wish it to you. I think this honourable lorddid but try us this other day.
dialogs.translated: You too. This feels familiar.

dialogs.original: Upon that were my thoughts tiring, when weencountered: I hope it is not so low with him ashe made it seem in the trial of his several friends.
dialogs.translated: I was just thinking that when we met. I hope things are not so bad that Timon has had to borrow more from his friends.

dialogs.original: It should not be, by the persuasion of his new feasting.
dialogs.translated: From what I see at this feast, I don't think so.

dialogs.original: I should think so: he hath sent me an earnest    inviting, which many my near occasions did urge me    to put off;   but he hath conjured me beyond them, and    I must needs appear.
dialogs.translated: I do. He sent me an invitation, and when I said I had other engagements, he pressed me further and told me I had to come.

dialogs.original: In like manner was I in debt to my importunate    business, but he would not hear my excuse.   I am    sorry, when he sent to borrow of me, that my    provision was out.
dialogs.translated: I also said I needed to deal with some business matters, but he didn't care. I am not happy to say it, but when he asked me for money, I had no more left to give him.

dialogs.original: I am sick of that grief too, as I understand how allthings go.
dialogs.translated: Same with me. I know how it is.

dialogs.original: Every man here's so. What would he have borrowed ofyou?
dialogs.translated: So does everyone here. How much money did he ask you for?

dialogs.original: A thousand pieces.
dialogs.translated: A thousand pieces.

dialogs.original: A thousand pieces!
dialogs.translated: A thousand pieces!

dialogs.original: What of you?
dialogs.translated: What did he ask you for?

dialogs.original: He sent to me, sir,Here he comes.
dialogs.translated: He asked me forhere he is.

dialogs.original: With all my heart, gentlemen both; and how fare you?
dialogs.translated: Greetings, gentleman. How are you?

dialogs.original: Ever at the best, hearing well of your lordship.
dialogs.translated: Well, especially after seeing that you are well, too.

dialogs.original: The swallow follows not summer more willing than weyour lordship.
dialogs.translated: We care as much about you as a bird that flies south cares for summer weather.

dialogs.original: [Aside]   Nor more willingly leaves winter; such    summer-birds are men.   Gentlemen, our dinner will not    recompense this long stay: feast your ears with the    music awhile, if they will fare so harshly o' the    trumpet's sound; we shall to 't presently.
dialogs.translated: [To himself] And you and other men have left me with the readiness that the bird flees from winter weather.[To the others] Dinner is getting cold, gentlemen! Enjoy the music, if you like such humble playing. Let's go.

dialogs.original: I hope it remains not unkindly with your lordshipthat I returned you an empty messenger.
dialogs.translated: I hope you are not bitter that I could not lend you money.

dialogs.original: O, sir, let it not trouble you.
dialogs.translated: Don't worry about it.

dialogs.original: My noble lord,
dialogs.translated: My noble lord

dialogs.original: Ah, my good friend, what cheer?
dialogs.translated: [As the banquet is being prepared] What a party!

dialogs.original: My most honourable lord, I am e'en sick of shame,that, when your lordship this other day sent to me,I was so unfortunate a beggar.
dialogs.translated: Timon, I feel so bad that I had no money left to give you when you asked me.

dialogs.original: Think not on 't, sir.
dialogs.translated: Don't worry about it.

dialogs.original: If you had sent but two hours before,
dialogs.translated: If you had come just two hours earlier

dialogs.original: Let it not cumber your better remembrance.
dialogs.translated: Think about happier things.

dialogs.original: Come, bring in all together.
dialogs.translated: Come here, the food is ready!

dialogs.original: All covered dishes!
dialogs.translated: It must be good food if you cover it this way!

dialogs.original: Royal cheer, I warrant you.
dialogs.translated: It looks like food for kings.

dialogs.original: Doubt not that, if money and the season can yieldit.
dialogs.translated: As long as he has enough money and time, I would count on it from Timon.

dialogs.original: How do you? What's the news?
dialogs.translated: [To the THIRD LORD] Oh how are you? What is new with the world?

dialogs.original: Alcibiades is banished: hear you of it?
dialogs.translated: Did you hear that Alcibiades is banished?

dialogs.original: Alcibiades banished!
dialogs.translated: What? Alcibiades is banished?

dialogs.original: 'Tis so, be sure of it.
dialogs.translated: I swear.

dialogs.original: How! how!
dialogs.translated: What? How?

dialogs.original: I pray you, upon what?
dialogs.translated: Why?

dialogs.original: My worthy friends, will you draw near?
dialogs.translated: Come here, my friends.

dialogs.original: I'll tell you more anon. Here's a noble feast toward.
dialogs.translated: I'll tell you about it later. Let's eat now.

dialogs.original: This is the old man still.
dialogs.translated: You speak of the famous Alcibiades?

dialogs.original: Will 't hold? will 't hold?
dialogs.translated: Can it be? Will the punishment stick?

dialogs.original: It does: but time willand so
dialogs.translated: Yes, but time will tell

dialogs.original: I do conceive.
dialogs.translated: I see.

dialogs.original: Each man to his stool, with that spur as he would to    the lip of his mistress: your diet shall be in all    places alike.   Make not a city feast of it, to let    the meat cool ere we can agree upon the first place:    sit, sit. The gods require our thanks.    You great benefactors, sprinkle our society with    thankfulness. For your own gifts, make yourselves    praised: but reserve still to give, lest your    deities be despised.   Lend to each man enough, that    one need not lend to another; for, were your    godheads to borrow of men, men would forsake the    gods.   Make the meat be beloved more than the man    that gives it. Let no assembly of twenty be without    a score of villains: if there sit twelve women at    the table, let a dozen of them beas they are.   The    rest of your fees, O godsthe senators of Athens,    together with the common lag of peoplewhat is    amiss in them, you gods, make suitable for    destruction.   For these my present friends, as they    are to me nothing, so in nothing bless them, and to    nothing are they welcome.    Uncover, dogs, and lap.
dialogs.translated: Go to your chairs as hungrily as you might kiss the lips of your mistress. There are no assigned seats, when the food gets cold before people find out where they sit. Sit, sit, and thank the gods. I thank you for the gifts you have given, and hope you will keep enough for yourselves so that you can still be so charitable in the future. You should have given enough that no man will have to give his own money to another, because even gods would not be successful in applying for a loan nowadays. Enjoy the meat more than you enjoy the man who provides you with it. Make sure also that twenty out of twenty men are villains, as you might let twelve women at a table be as they are. As for the rest, the senators and the commoners, destroy the worst parts of them.[Gesturing to the people around him]  My friends here, they mean nothing to me, so bless them with nothing. Here they are welcome to nothing. Uncover the dishes so the dogs may lick up the water.

dialogs.original: What does his lordship mean?
dialogs.translated: What is this supposed to mean?

dialogs.original: I know not.
dialogs.translated: I don't know.

dialogs.original: May you a better feast never behold,    You knot of mouth-friends I smoke and lukewarm water    Is your perfection.   This is Timon's last;    Who, stuck and spangled with your flatteries,    Washes it off, and sprinkles in your faces    Your reeking villany.
dialogs.translated: All you bottom-feeders, water and steam is the perfect meal for you, and I hope you never eat a better feast than this for the rest of your lives. I, who endured all your flattery, wash myself of it and return to you your wickedness.

dialogs.original: Live loathed and long,    Most smiling, smooth, detested parasites,    Courteous destroyers, affable wolves, meek bears,    You fools of fortune, trencher-friends, time's flies,    Cap and knee slaves, vapours, and minute-jacks!    Of man and beast the infinite malady    Crust you quite o'er! What, dost thou go?    Soft! take thy physic firstthou tooand thou;    Stay, I will lend thee money, borrow none.
dialogs.translated: I hope you live long and painful lives, you smooth-talking parasites, you wolves in sheeps' clothing, you weak fools of fortune, fake friends, worthless workers! You'll die soon enough! May the worst disease cover you all over in scabs! What, are you leaving? Come now, everyone, take your medicine first! Come on, I'll give you money and ask for nothing back!

dialogs.original: What, all in motion? Henceforth be no feast,    Whereat a villain's not a welcome guest.    Burn, house! sink, Athens! henceforth hated be    Of Timon man and all humanity!
dialogs.translated: What, everyone's leaving? From now on, let there never be a feast where such villains are not welcome. Burn down the house! Destroy all of Athens! Timon will from now on hate all of humanity!

dialogs.original: How now, my lords!
dialogs.translated: What the hell was that?

dialogs.original: Know you the quality of Lord Timon's fury?
dialogs.translated: Have you ever seen someone as furious as Timon just now?

dialogs.original: Push! did you see my cap?
dialogs.translated: Psh! Have you seen my hat?

dialogs.original: I have lost my gown.
dialogs.translated: I can't find my coat.

dialogs.original: He's but a mad lord, and nought but humour sways him.He gave me a jewel th' other day, and now he hasbeat it out of my hat: did you see my jewel?
dialogs.translated: He's a madman, and his insanity is what drives him. He gave me a jewel the other day, and now he has beaten it out of my hat. Have you seen the jewel?

dialogs.original: Did you see my cap?
dialogs.translated: Have you seen my hat?

dialogs.original: Here 'tis.
dialogs.translated: Here it is.

dialogs.original: Here lies my gown.
dialogs.translated: And here's my coat.

dialogs.original: Let's make no stay.
dialogs.translated: Let's get out of here.

dialogs.original: Lord Timon's mad.
dialogs.translated: Timon is crazy.

dialogs.original: I feel 't upon my bones.
dialogs.translated: Yes I am sure of it.

dialogs.original: One day he gives us diamonds, next day stones.
dialogs.translated: One day he gives us diamonds, and the next day he throws stones at us!
